On Tue, Feb 21, 2012 at 2:29 PM, forshahzaib <forshahzaib@...> wrote:

>
>    - When user POSTs on /R, we would like user to provide full input of
>    parent-resource (R) & all of its sub-resources (SR1, SR2, .., SRN). This is
>    to optimize for bandwidth & unnecessary round-trips. Is it acceptable per
>    REST guidelines to accept input for multiple resources (& create those
>    resources) by POSTing under one resource?
>
> What a server does upon receiving a POST request is entirely up to the
server. It can create a hundred resources, or none at all. Having a single
POST create more than one resource is a great way to reduce network rounds
trips.

>
>    - Client should be able to fetch (GET) and update (PUT) the parent and
>    sub-resources individually once created.
>
> You will have to design your representations such that the client can
traverse from known resources to these newly created resources. One way
would be to have the server respond to the creation POST with a redirect to
the main resource (R). The representation of R would provide links to the
sub-resources. The client could then follow its nose to the individual
sub-resources as needed.

Peter
barelyenough.org

--20cf307d06be868baa04b994a9d1
